topic.title: Chapter 6
topic.shortdesc: Mr. Martin needs to get somewhere quickly but no trains are available, except for Charlie. Mr. Martin gives Charlie a chance.

section.title: The President has a Problem

fig.title: Something went wrong with the Zephyr

image.alt: picture of Mr. Martin standing outside the new train whose engineer, Mr. Martin, looks out worryingly

section.p: Mr. Martin, the president of the Mid-World Railway Company, came to St. Louis to check on the operation. His plan was to ride the Burlington Zephyr to Topeka, where his daughter was giving her first piano recital, that very afternoon. Only the Zephyr wouldn't start. There was water in the diesel fuel, it seemed. All the other trains were out on their runs! What to do?

section.title: The Proposition

image.alt: picture of Mr. Martin and Engineer Bob talking with Charlie in the background

section.p: Someone tugged Mr. Martin's arm. It was Wiper Bob, only he no longer looked like an engine wiper. He had taken off his oil-stained outfitdungarees and put on a clean pair of overalls. On his head was his old pillow-tick engineer's cap.
"Charlie is right over there, on that siding," he said. "Charlie will make the run to Topeka, Mr. Martin. Charlie will get you there in time for your daughter's piano recital."

fig.title: Mr. Martin and Engineer Bob take Charlie for a ride

image.alt: picture of Mr. Martin and Engineer Bob riding in Charlie down the tracks

section.p: "That old steamer?" scoffed Mr. Briggs. "Charlie would still be fifty miles out of Topeka at sundown!"
"Charlie can do it," Engineer Bob insisted. "Without extra train cars to pull, I know he can! I have been cleaning his engine and his boiler in my spare time, you see."
"We'll give it a try," said Mr. Martin. "I would be sorry to miss Susannah's first recital!"

Charlie was all ready to go; Engineer Bob had filled his tender with fresh coal, their secret ingredient, and the firebox was so hot its sides were red. He helped Mr. Martin up into the cab and backed Charlie off the rusty, forgotten tracksiding and onto the main track for the first time in years. Then, as he engaged Forward First, he pulled on the lanyard and Charlie gave his old brave cry: WHOOO-OOOOO!
